title: How to Recycle a Mattress

steps.headline: Contact your city’s recycling program to ask if they take bulk items.
steps.description:
Some cities have recycling programs that will take bulk items, but call to make sure that mattresses are included. Feel free to ask how they recycle them as well (so you know they’re not just taking it to a dump). Do a quick online search to access your city’s government website then search the site for their disposal and recycling guide. You might try clicking on a directory tab and following a link that says something along the lines of “Health, Safety, and Services” or “Neighborhood Programs.”
If you live in California, Connecticut, or Rhode Island, you can use Bye Bye Mattress, a state-sponsored organization that ensures old mattresses don’t end up in landfills. The recycled mattresses will be taken apart and all the materials (steel, foam, fabric, and wood) will be reused for new products.

steps.headline: Call a local bulk hauling service and ask about their recycling options.
steps.description: Use an online search engine to look up professional “junk” hauling services and call or email them to see if they recycle mattresses or just take them to the dump. Keep in mind that these companies charge for their hauling services. Tell them all the items you want them to pick up. They’ll give you a quote for the job (which is typically based on the quantity, weight, or volume of items) and schedule a time window for pickup.

steps.headline: Ask your retailer if they’re partnered with a recycling service.
steps.description:
If you’re buying a new mattress and having it delivered, ask your retailer if they’ll remove and recycle your old mattress. Some companies will just remove it and take it to the dump, so put emphasis on the word “recycle.”
If they’re not partnered with a particular recycling service but you know of one, feel free to share that information with them and, if possible, request that they take it there. Check the warranty on your old mattress, as some sellers or manufacturers offer buy-back and/or free disposal services.

steps.headline: Vacuum, spot clean, and deodorize the mattress.
steps.description: Vacuum the mattress on both sides and use upholstery cleaner or diluted vinegar to treat any stains. Sprinkle some baking soda onto the surface and leave it for 20 minutes before vacuuming again to leave a fresh scent. As an alternative, combine 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of dish detergent with 1 cup (240 mL) of water to make a simple cleaning solution. Rub it in with a cloth or toothbrush to penetrate the fibers. Donation centers aren’t likely to take soiled mattresses, so get it in good condition before contacting them. Deep clean your mattress if it’s over 10 years old and has lots of set-in stains.

steps.headline: Call local thrift stores to find out if they accept mattresses.
steps.description: Some secondhand stores will accept mattresses and either try to sell them or, if they’re damaged or dirty, haul them away to recycling centers. Each locality has different rules about the items they accept and what they do with rejected items (recycle them or take them to the dump), so call ahead. Some organizations will pick up bulk items if you live within a certain mile radius of the donation center. The Salvation Army, Goodwill, and St. Vincent de Paul are good places to call about donating.

steps.headline: Contact disaster relief, homeless, or refugee centers.
steps.description: People in need of a place to sleep can certainly benefit from your old mattress. Nonprofits serving these populations will likely state what exactly they need on their websites. If you find a center that doesn’t have a “wish list” on their website, call to make sure before taking it to one of their donation centers. Make sure to look up disaster relief, homeless, and refugee centers specifically in your city and state. For instance, you might type “Mesa Arizona refugee center donations” or “Los Angeles California homeless shelter donations” into your online search engine. Make sure your mattress is clean and free of bed bugs.

steps.headline: Take pictures and post it on Craigslist in the free section.
steps.description: There’s probably someone in your area that will happily take your mattress for free. Be sure to clean it beforehand and take good pictures so you'll get more inquiries. List the size, manufacturer, and condition of the mattress (i.e., if it has wear and tear, stains, or depressions) in the ad as well. If you can’t transport the mattress, let them know that they’ll need to have a large car or truck to take it home.

steps.headline: Transport the mattress using a mattress protector, large vehicle, and rope.
steps.description: Cover the mattress in a mattress protector or wrap it in painter’s plastic to protect it from dust and debris. If you have access to a moving van, lean the mattress onto one of the inside walls. You can also lay it flat onto the bed of a pickup (propping it up on one side if it’s too wide to fit) and secure it with rope. To tie it to the roof of a smaller vehicle, center the mattress onto the roof and tie it 4 times across with a long rope (about 20 foot (6.7 yd) long). Run the rope through each window except the driver’s window. Drive slow and make sure to check the weather!

methods.name: Dismantling Your Mattress for Creative Reuse

steps.headline: Use a box cutter or utility knife to cut the cording around your mattress.
steps.description: The cording thread runs around the circumference of the mattress on both sides (it typically looks like rope). Cut through it and pull it away from the fabric. Set the cord aside to be recycled. Use the cord for any craft projects that call for fabric rope or twine.

steps.headline: Remove the fabric from the sides, top, and bottom.
steps.description: As you pull away the fabric from the entire mattress, use pliers to remove the staples holding it into place at various sections. You’ll see some foam or fluffy padding underneath. Take the fabric to a recycling center as is or use it as a unique canvas for an art project.

steps.headline: Wear gloves to collect the foam or fluffy padding.
steps.description: You might want to put on some cut-resistant gloves for this part in case loose staples have fallen into the padding. Grab the fluff or peel away the foam and store it into a box or bag. Remove the bottom layer of fiber if your mattress has extra padding just above the springs. You can use either type of padding to stuff pillows. You can also recycle or compost the cotton parts (but not the foam).

steps.headline: Remove the layer of metal springs for creative reuse or recycling.
steps.description: The final layer of the mattress is made up of metal springs and coils. Use bolt cutters or wire cutters to break this layer up into little pieces if you’re going to recycle it. Try cutting the coils away from the layer and mounting them on wood for a rustic-looking wine rack. Leave the entire layer intact and hang it on a wall to hold jewelry, photos, or small plants. You can also use the whole layer as a trellis for climbing vines (like ivy, jasmine, or bougainvillea).

steps.headline: Use pliers to remove the staples and fabric from the bottom edges of the frame.
steps.description: Box springs are typically wrapped in a layer of fabric to hide the wood frame. Use a pair of pliers to take out the staples securing the fabric and fluffy lining so you can pull it away from the wood. This fabric and lining can be recycled or folded and stuffed in other materials to make pillows or pet beds. If your box spring has a dust cover, cut it at the corners and tear it away.

steps.headline: Wear work gloves and goggles to break down the wood with a saw.
steps.description: If you want to break down the wood frame into small planks, make sure your hands and eyes are protected from splinters (especially if you’re using a power saw). Cut them into smaller pieces to be recycled or used for other woodworking projects. Check to see if your wood frame has any metal parts—you’ll need to remove those before taking it to a recycling center. Use a section of the frame (and reinforce the holes with more wood) to make a flat-bottomed hanging swing. Leave the wood frame whole and hammer wooden planks across the top to make a small, raised stage or outdoor seating area. Make sure to treat the wood with a finishing stain for outdoor use.
